cleaned_text: Chinese herbology Traditional Chinese herbal therapy / From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Dear Wikiwand AI, let's keep it short by simply answering these key questions: Can you list the top facts and stats about Chinese herbology? Summarize this article for a 10 years old Chinese is the theory of traditional Chinese herbal therapy, which accounts for the majority of treatments in [traditional Chinese medicine](/en/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) (TCM). A [Nature](/en/Nature_(journal)) editorial described TCM as "fraught with [pseudoscience](/en/Pseudoscience)", and said that the most obvious reason why it has not delivered many cures is that the majority of its treatments have no logical [mechanism of action](/en/Mechanism_of_action). [[1]](#cite_note-swallow-1) |Part of |[History of science and technology in China](/en/History_of_science_and_technology_in_China) The term [herbology](/en/Herbology) is misleading in the sense that, while plant elements are by far the most commonly used substances, animal, human, and mineral products are also used, among which some are poisonous. In the [Huangdi Neijing](/en/Huangdi_Neijing) they are referred to as (pinyin: dúyào) which means toxin, poison, or medicine. Paul U. Unschuld points out that this is similar etymology to the Greek [pharmakon](/en/Pharmakon_(philosophy)) and so he uses the term pharmaceutic. [[2]](#cite_note-2) Thus, the term medicinal (instead of herb) is usually preferred as a translation for (pinyin: yào). [[3]](#cite_note-3) Research into the effectiveness of traditional Chinese herbal therapy is of poor quality and often tainted by bias, [[4]](#cite_note-Shang-2007-4) with little or no rigorous evidence of efficacy.
